name: Rep. Bruce Westerman

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: Ms. Caraway served two full terms in the Senate, which included committee assignments on Agriculture and Forestry. On her final day in office, she received a standing ovation from her all-male colleagues.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: The governor appointed Ms. Caraway, but Ms. Caraway surprised everyone when she announced she would run for a full term. "The time has passed when a woman should be placed in a position and kept there only while someone else is being groomed for the job," she told reporters.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: Up first is Ms. Hattie Caraway, the first woman elected to the U.S. Senate in 1932. As a resident of Jonesboro, AR, Ms. Caraway initially became involved in politics when her husband, Senator Thaddeus Caraway, died in office in 1931.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text:
So what do we do? Start by recognizing that scientific practices like thinning allow trees to thrive and mitigate fire risk.

As urban areas continue growing larger and closer to forests, we can't deny the issues at stake. Sound forest management must be our future.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text:
Refusing to manage forests isn't environmentally friendly, it's just bad science. Dead, diseased trees are not only releasing carbon into the air, but they're also posing a greater fire risk.

Rather than acknowledging this, congressional Dems continue pushing impractical plans.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text:
Take, for example, this NYT story: "That area hasn‚Äôt seen any fire history since the 1940s,‚Äù Captain Volmer [a fire behavior analyst at Cal Fire] said, adding that the vegetation in that area is extremely dense, old and dry.

https://t.co/6NsNA1pDRO

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text:
During horrible natural disasters like the current fires in California, environmental activists immediately blame the GOP.

What they fail to mention are bills like the Resilient Federal Forests Act, which would use scientific forest management to fortify forests against fires.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: This so-called attempt to "save the internet" is a gift to edge providers who want to market personal data. GOP members have introduced three bills that would protect consumers without government involvement ‚Äì let‚Äôs focus our attention on those practical solutions instead.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: This isn‚Äôt the first time we‚Äôve debated net neutrality. When Trump first announced he was repealing regulations, liberals wouldn't stop talking about how this would radically change the internet as we knew it. But when the regulations ceased, these doomsday predictions fell flat.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: I support the bipartisan and commonsense "bright line" rules for net neutrality ‚Äì no blocking, no throttling and no paid prioritization ‚Äì that protect consumers, but the Save the Internet Act reaches far beyond these commonsense protections.

name: Rep. Bruce Westerman
tweet_text: The internet isn‚Äôt broken, so why are liberals trying to fix it? In H.R. 1644, House Democrats want to give federal entities nearly unlimited authority to regulate the internet, which is why I voted against it.
